examples.hindi_explanation: Umar ich apna hero (subject) hai yahan. Jab hero kuch karra nahi, bas wahan hai, toh usku Nominative ich rakhne ka. Change nakko karo.

examples.english: In old age one becomes wise.
examples.hindi_sentence: Budhape mein insaan hoshiyaar ho jaata.
examples.english_explanation: 'Im' stands for 'In dem'. When you are 'in' a stage of life, you are stuck there for a while. No movement out. So we use the Dative case.
examples.hindi_explanation: 'Im' bole toh 'In + dem'. Budhape ke andar ghus gaye, ab hilre nahi wahan se. Jab jagah fix ho jaati na, toh Dative lagate ustaad.

examples.english_explanation: In German slang, young people say 'Alter' to call their friends. It's like saying 'Bro' or 'Dude'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Ye German potte 'Alter' bolte apne doston ku. Jaisa apan 'Miya' ya 'Bhai' bolte na, waisa ich hai ye. Izzat se nahi, dosti mein bolre.

mnemonic: Imagine you Beat an Offer (anbieten).

details.conjugation_present: ich biete an, du bietest an, er bietet an

examples.hindi_sentence: Main tereku kuch offer karun kya?
examples.english_explanation: When you offer something TO someone, that person is the Receiver. In German, the Receiver is always in the Dative case. So 'du' becomes 'dir'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Dekh bhai, apan kisiku kuch dere (offer karre). Jisku dere na, wo Dative ban jaata. Isliye 'Du' nahi 'Dir' bolne ka. Receiver hai wo.

examples.english_explanation: This verb is like a Lego block that breaks apart. 'Bieten' stays with 'We', and 'an' goes all the way to the end. Separable verb!
examples.hindi_explanation: Ye verb toot jaata miya. 'Bieten' sentence ke beech mein rehta aur 'an' ku utha ke last mein phek dete. Isku bolte separable verb.

examples.english_explanation: This is past tense. We use 'hat' + the ge-word (angeboten). It means the offer already happened.
examples.hindi_explanation: Ye purani baat hai (Past tense). 'Hat' lagaye aur 'angeboten' bole. Une madad offer kar diya, baat khatam.

mnemonic: Das = Baby. Imagine a BABY grabbing a special Angebot.

examples.english_explanation: A simple sentence. A is B. The offer is good. The offer is the Subject, so it stays Nominative.
examples.hindi_explanation: Seedhi baat hai, offer accha hai. Offer ich main hero hai, toh Nominative case rakhne ka. Tension nakko.

examples.german: Das Angebot an Obst ist groß.
examples.english: The offer (range) of fruit is large.
examples.hindi_sentence: Phal ka stock bohot bada hai.
examples.english_explanation: Here 'Angebot' means the variety or supply available. It is still the Subject (Nominative).
examples.hindi_explanation: Yahan 'Angebot' bole toh dukaan mein kitna maal hai. Ye bhi subject ich hai, isliye change nahi hota.

examples.english_explanation: To say something is 'on sale', Germans say 'in the offer' (im Angebot). Memorize this phrase!
examples.hindi_explanation: Agar bolna hai ke sale chalri, toh German mein bolte 'Im Angebot'. Ratta maar lo, 'sale' bole toh 'im Angebot'.

mnemonic: Imagine Under another (ander) umbrella.

examples.english: I would like the other book.
examples.english_explanation: You want the book (Object). The book is neutral (Das). So the adjective adds an 'e' at the end -> 'andere'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Mereku wo 'dusri' wali book chahiye. Book object hai, aur 'Das' wali hai. Isliye 'ander' ke aage 'e' laga diye -> 'andere'.

examples.english_explanation: Here 'die anderen' refers to 'the other people'. It acts like a noun and is the Subject.
examples.hindi_explanation: 'Die anderen' bole toh 'dusre logaan'. Ye logaan subject hain, aare na? Isliye Nominative plural.

examples.german: Am anderen Morgen war er weg.
examples.english: The next morning he was gone.
examples.english_explanation: A fixed phrase for 'the next morning'. 'Am' (on the) triggers Dative, so 'ander' becomes 'anderen'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Ye phrase hai ustaad. 'Am' ke baad hamesha Dative aata, isliye 'ander' ke peeche 'en' laga diye -> 'anderen'.

mnemonic: Imagine a Fang starting (anfangen) to bite.

details.conjugation_present: ich fange an, du fängst an, er fängt an

examples.german: Der Film fängt um 8 Uhr an.
examples.english_explanation: Separable verb! 'Fängt' stays in position 2, and 'an' goes to the very end of the sentence.
examples.hindi_explanation: Ye verb toot jaata dekho. 'Fängt' beech mein rehta aur 'an' ko utha ke aakhri mein phek dete. German style hai ye.

examples.english_explanation: When you start DOING something else (eating), use 'zu' before the second verb -> 'zu essen'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Jab koi doosra kaam (khaana) shuru karre, toh 'zu' lagana padta -> 'zu essen'.

examples.english_explanation: The path is the Subject. 'Anfangen' splits up again.
examples.hindi_explanation: Raasta shuru hora. Raasta subject hai. Verb waisa ich tootenga -> 'fängt ... an'.

mnemonic: Der = Man. Imagine a MAN at the very Anfang of the race.

examples.english_explanation: A famous German proverb. 'Anfang' is the Subject (Nominative).
examples.hindi_explanation: Ye purani kahawat hai. Shuruat ich mushkil rehti. 'Anfang' subject hai, isliye Nominative.

examples.english: In the beginning it was dark.
examples.english_explanation: 'Am' stands for 'An dem'. A specific point in time means no movement, so we use Dative.
examples.hindi_explanation: 'Am' bole toh 'An + dem'. Shuruat ke waqt (fixed time), isliye Dative case lagaye.

examples.english_explanation: A fixed phrase. 'Von' always triggers Dative, but here we usually just memorize the phrase.
examples.hindi_explanation: Ye phrase ratta maar lo. 'Von Anfang an'. Iska matlab 'shuruat se'.

mnemonic: Imagine Clicking on (anklicken) the mouse.

details.conjugation_present: ich klicke an, du klickst an, er klickt an

examples.english_explanation: You are clicking the picture (Object). So 'das Bild' is Accusative (but Das stays Das).
examples.hindi_explanation: Photo ku click karna hai. Photo object hai. 'Das' change nahi hota, tension nakko lo.

examples.english_explanation: I clicked WHAT? The link. The link is masculine (Der Link), so it changes to 'Den Link' (Accusative).
examples.hindi_explanation: Link ku click kare na? Link 'Der' hai, toh Accusative mein 'Den' ban jaata. Object hai wo.

examples.english_explanation: 'Mit' (with) always takes the Dative case. 'Die Maus' becomes 'Der Maus' in Dative.
examples.hindi_explanation: 'Mit' (se) ke baad hamesha Dative aata. Isliye 'Die Maus' badal ke 'Der Maus' ho gayi. Ye German logic hai miya.

mnemonic: Imagine saying 'Come on, Arrive!' (ankommen).

details.conjugation_present: ich komme an, du kommst an, er kommt an

examples.english_explanation: Separable verb. 'Kommt' stays second, 'an' goes last. Train is the Subject.
examples.hindi_explanation: Train kab aari? Train subject hai. Verb toot ke 'an' aakhri mein gir jaata.

examples.english_explanation: Arriving implies movement/change of location. So we use 'sind' (sein) as the helper verb, not 'haben'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Kyunki apan ek jagah se dusri jagah pahunche (movement), isliye 'haben' nahi 'sind' lagana padta. Rule hai ye.

examples.english_explanation: A very common idiom. When you aren't sure, just say 'Es kommt darauf an'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Jab confirm nahi bol sakte, toh ye bolne ka: 'Es kommt darauf an'. Iska matlab 'wo depend karta' ya 'halaa't pe hai'.

mnemonic: Die = Woman. Imagine a WOMAN waiting for the Ankunft.

examples.english_explanation: The arrival is the main thing we are talking about. Subject = Nominative.
examples.hindi_explanation: Arrival ich subject hai yahan. Late hai bole toh late hai. Nominative case.

examples.english: We are waiting at the arrival (area).
examples.hindi_sentence: Hum arrival gate pe wait karre.
examples.english_explanation: 'Bei' means 'at' or 'near'. It always triggers the Dative case. 'Die Ankunft' becomes 'Der Ankunft'.
examples.hindi_explanation: 'Bei' ke baad Dative aata ustaad. Isliye 'Die' badal ke 'Der' ho gaya. Logic simple hai.
Uska aana (arrival) subject hai. Nominative case.

english: to mark with a cross / tick
mnemonic: Imagine drawing a Cross (Kreuz) on it.

details.conjugation_present: ich kreuze an, du kreuzt an, er kreuzt an

examples.hindi_sentence: Zara sahi jawaab pe tick karo.
examples.english_explanation: You are marking the answer (Object). So 'die Antwort' is Accusative.
examples.hindi_explanation: Jawaab ku tick karna hai. Jawaab object hai, Accusative case.

examples.english_explanation: Past tense. Separable verbs put the 'ge' in the middle: an-ge-kreuzt.
examples.hindi_explanation: Past tense mein 'ge' beech mein ghus jaata: an-ge-kreuzt. Maine tick kar diya.

examples.english_explanation: 'Müssen' (must) sends the main verb 'ankreuzen' to the end of the sentence.
examples.hindi_explanation: 'Müssen' bole toh karna padta. Jab ye aata, toh main verb 'ankreuzen' dum daba ke last mein bhaag jaata.

mnemonic: Imagine Making it on (anmachen).

details.conjugation_present: ich mache an, du machst an, er macht an

examples.english: Can you turn on the light?
examples.english_explanation: You are turning on the LIGHT (Object). 'Das Licht' stays 'Das Licht' in Accusative.
examples.hindi_explanation: Light ku on karna hai. Light object hai. 'Das' change nahi hota.

examples.english_explanation: I am turning on the TV. TV is masculine (Der). So it changes to 'Den Fernseher' (Accusative).
examples.hindi_explanation: TV lagaare na? TV 'Der' hai, toh Accusative mein 'Den' ban jaata. Object hai wo.

examples.english_explanation: Same logic. Starting the fire. Separable verb: machen ... an.
examples.hindi_explanation: Aag jalaare. Verb toot jaata: 'machen ... an'. German style.

mnemonic: Imagine Melding (melden) into the group by Registering (anmelden).

details.conjugation_present: ich melde mich an, du meldest dich an, er meldet sich an

examples.meaning_label: Meaning: To sign up for a course
examples.german: Ich muss mich für den Deutschkurs anmelden.
examples.english: I must register for the German course.
examples.hindi_sentence: Mereku German course ke liye naam likhwana hai.
examples.english_explanation: Reflexive verb (register myself). 'Für' (for) always takes Accusative -> 'den Kurs'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Khud ka naam likhwana hai (reflexive). 'Für' ke baad hamesha Accusative aata -> 'den Kurs'.

examples.german: Haben Sie sich an der Rezeption angemeldet?
examples.english: Have you checked in at the reception?
examples.hindi_sentence: Kya aap reception pe entry karaye?
examples.english_explanation: 'An' here means 'at' a location (Reception). Static location = Dative.
examples.hindi_explanation: Reception 'pe' khade hoke entry karana hai. Jagah fix hai, toh Dative case lagana.

examples.english_explanation: Simple sentence with a modal verb 'können' (can).
examples.hindi_explanation: Login nai hora miya. Simple sentence hai.

mnemonic: Die = Woman. Imagine a WOMAN filling out the Anmeldung form.

examples.english_explanation: Asking for location of the subject. Nominative case.
examples.hindi_explanation: Reception kahan hai poochre. Subject hai, change nakko karo.

examples.english: The registration takes a long time.
examples.hindi_explanation: Registration ku time lagra. Subject hai wo.

examples.english_explanation: You are filling the FORM (Object). Accusative. (Die stays Die).
examples.hindi_explanation: Form bharo miya. Form object hai. 'Die' change nahi hota.

mnemonic: Die = Woman. Imagine a WOMAN choosing a polite Anrede.

examples.hindi_sentence: Start sahi nahi kiya (greeting galat hai).
examples.english_explanation: Subject Nominative. Simple A is B sentence.
examples.hindi_explanation: Greeting galat hai. Subject hai ye.
Kaunsa wala fit hora? Subject poochre.
'Auf' ke baad Accusative aata. Greeting pe dhyan do.

mnemonic: Imagine calling on the Roof (rufen) - Anrufen.

details.conjugation_present: ich rufe an, du rufst an, er ruft an

examples.hindi_sentence: Main tereku baad mein phone kartau.
examples.english_explanation: Important: Calling someone uses the Accusative case (dich), NOT Dative (dir). You are 'dialing' the person.
examples.hindi_explanation: Yaad rakho: Phone karte waqt samne wala Accusative hota (Dich). Dative (Dir) nakko lagao. Ratta maaro isku.

examples.english_explanation: Command form. 'Die Polizei' is Accusative object.
examples.hindi_explanation: Order dere. Police object hai. Phone lagao jaldi.
Une mereku (Mich) phone kiya. Accusative hai apan.

mnemonic: Der = Man. Imagine a MAN waiting for an important Anruf.

examples.english: I am waiting for a call.
examples.hindi_sentence: Main ek call ka wait karrau.
examples.english_explanation: 'Warten auf' always takes Accusative. Masculine 'Ein' becomes 'Einen'.
examples.hindi_explanation: 'Warten auf' bole toh Accusative pakka. 'Ein' ban gaya 'Einen'.

examples.hindi_sentence: Tera ek call miss ho gaya.
examples.english_explanation: You missed WHAT? A call (Object). Accusative -> 'Einen Anruf'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Kya miss hua? Call. Call object hai, isliye Accusative.

examples.english_explanation: The call is the Subject. Nominative.
examples.hindi_explanation: Call subject hai. Change nakko karo.

mnemonic: Der = Man. Imagine a MAN speaking to the Anrufbeantworter.

examples.english_explanation: You are directing your voice ONTO the machine. Movement = Accusative (Den).
examples.hindi_explanation: Awaaz machine ke upar phek rahe (movement). Isliye Accusative (Den) lagaye.

examples.english: I am listening to the machine.
examples.english_explanation: I am checking the machine (Object). Accusative (Den).
examples.hindi_explanation: Machine ku check karre. Object hai. Den ban gaya.
Machine full hai. Subject hai. Nominative.

mnemonic: Die = Woman. Imagine a WOMAN making a loud Ansage.

examples.hindi_explanation: 'Auf' ke baad Accusative aata. Announcement suno miya.

examples.english_explanation: Here 'Ansage' implies a strict order or statement. Subject Nominative.
examples.hindi_explanation: Bhai ne bol diya toh bol diya. Clear order tha wo.

examples.hindi_sentence: Phone pe jo recording bajti na.
examples.english_explanation: 'Am Telefon' = Dative (location). The announcement is the subject.

mnemonic: Der = Man. Imagine a MAN missing his train Anschluss.

examples.english_explanation: I missed WHAT? The connection (Object). Masculine 'Der' becomes 'Den'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Kya chhoot gaya? Connection. Object hai, isliye 'Den' ban gaya.

examples.english_explanation: Idiom: Not fitting in. 'Keinen' because it's Accusative.
examples.hindi_explanation: Wo set nahi hora group mein. Connection nahi milra.

mnemonic: Imagine the light is On (an).

details.conjugation_present: ich bin an, du bist an, er ist an

examples.hindi_explanation: Light chalu hai. Bas haalat batare.
Gas chalu hai kya? Poochre bas.

examples.english_explanation: Short for 'anhaben'. What are you wearing?
examples.hindi_explanation: Kya pehna hai? 'An' bole toh 'on your body'.

mnemonic: Imagine giving an Answer (Antwort).

details.conjugation_present: ich antworte, du antwortest, er antwortet

examples.english_explanation: CRITICAL: 'Antworten' takes DATIVE for the person. Answer TO me. So 'Mir', not 'Mich'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Bhai, 'Antworten' ke saath insaan Dative hota. Mereku (Mir) jawaab do. 'Mich' nakko bolo.

examples.meaning_label: Meaning: Reply to a specific topic
examples.german: Er antwortet nicht auf die Frage.
examples.english: He is not answering the question.
examples.hindi_sentence: Une sawaal ka jawaab nai dera.
examples.hindi_explanation: Sawaal ka jawaab dena hai toh 'auf' lagao aur Accusative chipkao.

examples.english_explanation: Boss is a person -> Dative case. 'Der Chef' becomes 'Dem Chef'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Boss insaan hai na? Toh Dative lagenga. 'Dem Chef' bolo.

mnemonic: Die = Woman. Imagine a WOMAN knowing the correct Antwort.

examples.german: Ich kenne die Antwort auf diese Frage nicht.
examples.english: I don't know the answer to this question.
examples.hindi_sentence: Mujhe is sawaal ka jawaab nahi maaloom.
examples.english_explanation: Imagine pointing your finger AT the question. That pointing is the word 'auf'. And because you are aiming at it, we use the Accusative case.
examples.hindi_explanation: Sawaal ka jawaab hona bole toh German mein 'auf' lagana padta miya. Aur 'auf' ke baad seedha Accusative laga dene ka. Dimagh pe zyaada zor nakko daalo.

examples.english_explanation: This is a super simple sentence. 'The answer' is the boss (Subject) here. We don't change anything. It stays Nominative.
examples.hindi_explanation: Ye toh ekdum seedha hisaab hai. 'Jawaab' ich main hero (subject) hai. Jab hero kuch karra nahi, bas khada hai, toh case change nahi karne ka. Nominative ich rakhna.

examples.german: Ich warte immer noch auf eine Antwort.
examples.english: I am still waiting for an answer.
examples.hindi_sentence: Main abhi bhi jawaab ka intezaar kar raha hoon.
examples.english_explanation: Magic rule! Whenever you use the verb 'warten' (to wait), you MUST use 'auf'. It's like a package deal: 'wait for' = 'warten auf'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Suno miya, 'wait' karne ka hai toh 'auf' chipkana padta. Ye dono judwaa bhai hain, alag nahi hote. 'Warten auf' bole toh Accusative pakka!

mnemonic: Die = Woman. Imagine a WOMAN reading an Anzeige in the paper.

examples.german: Ich habe die Anzeige in der Zeitung gelesen.
examples.english: I read the ad in the newspaper.
examples.english_explanation: Two things: 1. You read the Ad (Object), so it's Accusative. 2. The Ad is sitting INSIDE the paper (Location), so 'in the paper' is Dative.
examples.hindi_explanation: Dekho, Ad ko apan padh rahe, toh Ad ho gaya Accusative. Aur Ad kahan baitha hua hai? Paper ke andar. Hilra nahi na? Toh 'In' ke saath Dative laga daalo.

examples.german: Er hat eine Anzeige bei der Polizei erstattet.
examples.english: He filed a report with the police.
examples.english_explanation: Whenever you are 'at' someone's place or 'with' an institution like the police, use 'bei'. 'Bei' always triggers Dative.
examples.hindi_explanation: Jab bhi police ya kisi office ke paas jaate na, toh 'Bei' bolne ka. Aur 'Bei' ka scene clear hai ustaad - ye hamesha Dative ich maangta.

examples.german: Die Anzeige am Gerät ist kaputt.
examples.english: The display on the device is broken.
examples.english_explanation: 'Am' stands for 'An dem'. We use 'An' because the display is attached ON the side of the device. It's a fixed spot, so Dative!
examples.hindi_explanation: 'Am' bole toh 'An + dem'. Display hawa mein nahi hai, machine par chipka hua hai. Jagah fixed hai isliye Dative case use kare.

mnemonic: Imagine pulling (ziehen) clothes On (an).

details.conjugation_present: ich ziehe an, du ziehst an, er zieht an

examples.meaning_label: Meaning: To put on a specific item
examples.english: I am putting on my jacket.
examples.english_explanation: This verb splits up! 'Ziehe' stays with 'I', and 'an' goes to the very end. You are putting on the JACKET, so the jacket is the Object (Accusative).
examples.hindi_explanation: Ye verb toot jaata dekho. 'Ziehe' pehle aayega, aur 'an' ko utha ke sentence ke aakhri mein phek dene ka. Jacket pehenre na? Toh jacket Accusative hai.

examples.english_explanation: Here you aren't mentioning a specific shirt, just dressing YOURSELF. So we use the reflexive word 'dich' (yourself).
examples.hindi_explanation: Jab batana nahi hai ki kya pehenre, bas 'taiyar hona' hai, toh 'dich' (khud ko) lagana padta. Isku Reflexive bolte miya.

examples.english_explanation: Subject (Magnet) pulls Object (Iron). Same grammar rules, just a different meaning (attracting instead of dressing).
examples.hindi_explanation: Logic same hai ustaad. Magnet (hero) lohe (object) ko kheenchra. Bas yahan kapde nahi pehenre, physics chalra.

mnemonic: Das = Baby. Imagine a BABY crawling in a new Apartment.

examples.english: We are looking for a furnished apartment.
examples.english_explanation: We are LOOKING for it. So the apartment is the object of our search. But good news: for 'Das' words, the Accusative looks exactly like the Nominative!
examples.hindi_explanation: Apan flat dhoondre. Toh flat object hua na? Par tension nakko lo, 'Das' wale words change nahi hote. 'Ein' ka 'Ein' ich rehta.

examples.german: Sie wohnt in einem kleinen Apartment.
examples.english: She lives in a small apartment.
examples.hindi_sentence: Wo ek chhote flat mein rehti.
examples.english_explanation: She lives INSIDE it. She isn't moving, she is staying there. Static Location = Dative Case. 'Ein' becomes 'Einem'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Wo flat ke andar rehri, hilri nahi. Jab koi cheez ek jagah tikee hui ho, toh Dative lagate. Isliye 'Ein' ban gaya 'Einem'.

examples.english_explanation: The apartment is the star of the sentence (Subject). So it stays simply 'Das Apartment' (Nominative).
examples.hindi_explanation: Yahan flat ich apna hero hai (Subject). Kuch action nahi hora, bas rate batare. Toh simple 'Das' rakhne ka.

mnemonic: Der = Man. Imagine a MAN eating a red Apfel.

examples.german: Ich esse jeden Tag einen Apfel.
examples.english: I eat an apple every day.
examples.english_explanation: I am eating the apple. The apple is getting eaten (poor apple!). Because it's the Object and it's Masculine (Der), it changes to 'Einen'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Seb ko khaare miya. Seb object hai. Aur kyunki seb 'Der' (Masculine) hai, toh Accusative mein 'Ein' ban jaata 'Einen'. Ye rule dimaagh mein bitha lo!

examples.english_explanation: The apple is just sitting there being sour. It's the Subject. So we stick to 'Der' (Nominative).
examples.hindi_explanation: Yahan seb kuch karra nahi, bas khatta hai. Seb ich main subject hai, isliye 'Der' change nahi hota.

examples.english: Please buy a kilo of apples.
examples.english_explanation: In German, after measurement words like 'Kilo' or 'Liter', we don't say 'of'. We just stick the noun right after it. Simple!
examples.hindi_explanation: German mein 'Kilo of apples' nahi bolte. Seedha 'Ek Kilo Seb' bolte. Beech mein koi 'ka/ki' (von) nakko lagao.

mnemonic: Der = Man. Imagine a MAN with a huge Appetit.

examples.english_explanation: We are secretly saying 'I wish you a good appetite'. Because 'wishing' acts on the appetite, it becomes Accusative. That's why it's 'Guten'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Asliyat mein hum bolre 'Main tumku acchi bhookh wish karrau'. Toh bhookh object ban gayi na? Isliye 'Guten' lagaye. Ye shortcut hai miya.

examples.hindi_sentence: Aaj mereku bhookh ich nahi hai.
examples.english_explanation: The verb 'haben' (to have) is bossy. It ALWAYS demands the Accusative case. So 'Der Appetit' turns into 'Keinen Appetit'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Bhai, 'Haben' (to have) jahan dikha, samajh jao aage Accusative aata. Isliye 'Der' wala word ban gaya 'Keinen'. Light lo.

examples.english: The walk works up (makes) an appetite.
examples.english_explanation: The walk (Subject) is CREATING the appetite (Object). Subject acts on Object. Easy!
examples.hindi_explanation: Walk karne se bhookh banri. Toh Walk apna hero hai, aur bhookh object hai. Logic simple hai.

mnemonic: Imagine a Robot (Arbeit) working hard.

details.conjugation_present: ich arbeite, du arbeitest, er arbeitet

examples.english_explanation: If you work 'at' a specific company, use 'bei'. It's the standard preposition for 'at someone's place' and triggers Dative.
examples.hindi_explanation: Jab kisi company ke 'yahan' kaam karte na, toh 'in' nakko lagao, 'bei' lagao. Jaise 'Bei Google', 'Bei Tata'. Hau, Dative aata uske baad.

examples.hindi_sentence: Wo teacher ke jaisa kaam karta.
examples.english_explanation: To say 'as a...', use 'als'. Notice we don't say 'as A teacher', just 'as teacher'. No article needed!
examples.hindi_explanation: Agar bolna hai ki main 'teacher hun' ya 'engineer hun', toh 'als' use karo. Aur 'Ek' (Ein) lagane ki zaroorat ich nahi hai. Seedha 'Als Lehrer'.

examples.german: Wir arbeiten an einem neuen Projekt.
examples.english: We are working on a new project.
examples.hindi_sentence: Hum ek naye project pe kaam karre.
examples.english_explanation: When you work ON something, German uses 'an'. It triggers the Dative case here because you are busy 'at' that project.
examples.hindi_explanation: Kisi cheez 'par' kaam karre? Toh 'an' lagao. Aur ye Dative lega. Project pe dimaagh kharaab hora na!

mnemonic: Die = Woman. Imagine a WOMAN going to her Arbeit.

examples.german: Ich fahre mit dem Bus zur Arbeit.
examples.english: I go (drive) to work by bus.
examples.hindi_sentence: Main bus se kaam ku jaarau.
examples.english_explanation: 'Zur' is short for 'Zu der'. 'Zu' (to) is a Dative preposition. So 'Die Arbeit' changes to 'Der Arbeit'.
examples.hindi_explanation: 'Zur' bole toh 'Zu + der'. Jab kaam ku jaate na, toh 'Zu' lagta, aur 'Zu' hamesha Dative leta. Isliye 'Die' ban gaya 'Der'. Samjhe?

examples.english_explanation: The work is the Subject here. It's the thing being exhausting. So it stays 'Die Arbeit' (Nominative).
examples.hindi_explanation: Yahan 'kaam' ich subject hai. Kuch action nahi hora, bas batare ki kaam hard hai. Toh 'Die' ich rahenga.

examples.english_explanation: Here 'Arbeit' is a general concept, not a specific task. So we don't need 'the' or 'a'. Just 'He seeks work'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Wo koi ek specific kaam nahi dhoondra, bas 'naukri' dhoondra. Isliye 'die' ya 'eine' lagane ki zaroorat nakko.

mnemonic: Imagine being Work-less (arbeits-los).

examples.german: Mein Nachbar ist seit einem Jahr arbeitslos.
examples.english: My neighbor has been unemployed for a year.
examples.hindi_sentence: Mera padosi ek saal se bekaar baitha hai.
examples.english_explanation: The word 'seit' means 'since' or 'for'. It always triggers the Dative case. That's why 'Ein Jahr' becomes 'Einem Jahr'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Jab bolna ho 'kab se', toh 'seit' use karte. Aur 'seit' ke baad hamesha Dative aata. Isliye 'Einem' Jahr bole.

examples.english_explanation: 'Geworden' means 'became'. It shows a change from having a job to having no job.
examples.hindi_explanation: 'Geworden' bole toh 'ban gaye' ya 'ho gaye'. Pehle job thi, ab nahi hai. Haalat badal gayi miya.

examples.english: She must register herself as unemployed.
examples.hindi_sentence: Usku khud ku berozgaar register karana padta.
examples.english_explanation: This is a reflexive phrase: 'sich melden'. You are reporting YOURSELF to the office.
examples.hindi_explanation: Ye sarkari phrase hai. Office jaake 'khud ku' (sich) report karna padta ki bhai main khali hun, kuch dilao.

mnemonic: Der = Man. Imagine a MAN cleaning his Arbeitsplatz.

examples.english_explanation: My desk is the Subject. It's clean. Simple Nominative sentence.
examples.hindi_explanation: Seedhi baat hai: Meri desk (subject) saaf hai. Koi complication nahi, Nominative case ich.

examples.german: Er hat Angst um seinen Arbeitsplatz.
examples.english: He is afraid for his job.
examples.hindi_sentence: Usku naukri jaane ka darr hai.
examples.english_explanation: 'Angst haben um' means 'to fear FOR something'. The 'um' always demands Accusative. So 'Der' becomes 'Seinen'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Jab kisi cheez ki fikar ya darr ho, toh 'Angst um' bolte. Aur 'um' ke baad hamesha Accusative aata -> Seinen.

examples.english_explanation: The company creates WHAT? Jobs. So Jobs are the Direct Object (Accusative).
examples.hindi_explanation: Company kya banari? Jobs. Toh Jobs object huye na? Isliye ye Accusative case mein aayenge.

mnemonic: Der = Man. Imagine a MAN flexing his Arm.

examples.english_explanation: The arm is the one doing the hurting. It's the Subject. So it stays Nominative.
examples.hindi_explanation: Haath dukhra bhai. Haath ich subject hai. Isliye 'Mein' Arm bole, 'Meinen' nahi.

examples.german: Er hat sich den Arm gebrochen.
examples.english_explanation: Literally: 'He broke the arm for himself'. The arm is the object getting broken -> Accusative (Den Arm).
examples.hindi_explanation: Une haath tod liya. Haath object hai (Accusative). Aur khud ka toda isliye 'sich' lagaye.

examples.german: Sie nimmt das Kind in den Arm.
examples.english: She takes the child in her arm (hugs).
examples.hindi_sentence: Wo bachche ku godd mein leri.
examples.english_explanation: She moves the child INTO her arm. Movement = Accusative case. So 'Der Arm' becomes 'Den Arm'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Wo bachche ku godd mein 'leri' (movement hori). Jab movement hoti toh Accusative lagta. Der ban gaya Den.

mnemonic: Der = Man. Imagine a MAN who is an Art-ist at being an Arzt.

examples.german: Ich muss heute zum Arzt gehen.
examples.english: I must go to the doctor today.
examples.hindi_sentence: Mereku aaj doctor ke paas jaana hai.
examples.english_explanation: 'Zum' stands for 'Zu dem'. When you go TO a person, use 'zu'. And 'zu' always triggers Dative.
examples.hindi_explanation: Jab kisi insaan (doctor/bhai) ki taraf jaate na, toh 'zu' lagate. Aur 'zu' hamesha Dative leta. Isliye 'Dem Arzt' (Zum) bole.

examples.english_explanation: In German, if you say what your job is, you don't use 'a' (ein). You just say 'I am Doctor'.
examples.hindi_explanation: German mein job batate waqt 'Ek' (ein) nahi bolte. Bas bolo 'Wo Doctor hai'. Khalli pilli lamba nakko karo.

examples.hindi_sentence: Doctor ke paas time ich nahi hai.
examples.english_explanation: The doctor is the Subject. So 'Der Arzt' stays as it is (Nominative).
examples.hindi_explanation: Doctor subject hai miya, wo busy hai. Isliye 'Der' ich rahenga.

mnemonic: Imagine saying 'Ouch! Me too (auch)!'

examples.english_explanation: 'Auch' usually comes after the verb. It highlights the word 'hunger' here.
examples.hindi_explanation: Jisku highlight karna hai, 'Auch' wahan lagao. Mereku 'bhi' bhookh lagi bole jaisa.
'Bhi' adjective (possible) ku support karra. Ye bhi ho sakta ustaad.

examples.english: Are you coming to the party too?
examples.hindi_sentence: Tu bhi party ku aara kya?
examples.english_explanation: Asks if YOU are joining the others. 'Auch' modifies the subject 'du'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Poochra 'baaki sab aare, tu bhi aara kya?'. Hau, tereku ich poochra.

mnemonic: Imagine sitting Auf the roof.

examples.german: Das Buch liegt auf dem Tisch.
examples.english: The book is lying on the table.
examples.hindi_sentence: Book table par rakhi hui hai.
examples.english_explanation: The book is just L YING there. No movement. So we use the Dative case. 'Dem Tisch'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Book table ke upar padi hai, hilri nahi (no movement). Isliye Dative case laga -> 'Dem' Tisch.

examples.german: Ich lege das Buch auf den Tisch.
examples.english: I am putting the book on the table.
examples.english_explanation: Now you are MOVING the book onto the table. Action/Movement = Accusative case. 'Den Tisch'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Ab apan book ku table ke upar 'rakhre' (action horela hai). Isliye Accusative -> 'Den' Tisch.

examples.english: We are waiting for the bus.
examples.english_explanation: Remember: 'Warten auf' always takes Accusative. Don't ask why, just memorize it!
examples.hindi_explanation: Ratta maar lo miya: 'Wait' ke saath hamesha 'auf' aur Accusative aayenga. Kaiku bole toh kaiku.

mnemonic: Die = Woman. Imagine a WOMAN finishing a difficult Aufgabe.

examples.hindi_sentence: Tu tera homework kar liya kya?
examples.english_explanation: Homework is being DONE. It's the object. So Accusative case.
examples.hindi_explanation: Homework 'karre' na? Toh homework object hai, Accusative mein aayenga.

examples.german: Diese Aufgabe ist zu schwer für mich.

examples.hindi_sentence: Ye task mere liye bohot hard hai.
examples.english_explanation: 1. Task is Subject (Nominative). 2. 'Für' (for) always takes Accusative -> 'Für mich'.
examples.hindi_explanation: 1. Task hero hai yahan. 2. 'Für' (for) ke baad hamesha Accusative aata -> 'Für mich'.

examples.english_explanation: Simple sentence structure. A equals B. Nominative case.
examples.hindi_explanation: Simple sentence hai: Ye mera kaam nai hai. Isliye Nominative ich rahenga.

examples.english_explanation: This is a separable verb. 'Hören' stays in the normal spot, and 'auf' gets kicked to the end of the sentence.
examples.hindi_explanation: Verb toot jaata miya: 'Hören' sentence mein rehta aur 'Auf' ku utha ke last mein phek dete.

examples.hindi_sentence: Tu gaana band karta kya please?
examples.english_explanation: When stopping ANOTHER action (singing), we put 'zu' before that action -> 'zu singen'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Jab koi doosra action (gaana) rokna ho, toh 'zu' lagate -> 'zu singen'.

examples.english_explanation: Giving an order. We drop the 'du' and the 'st'. Just 'Hör'.

examples.english_explanation: In spoken German, 'auf' can mean 'open'. It's like asking 'Is the window up?'.

examples.english_explanation: Describing the state of the shop. 'Is' = 'ist'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Dukaan ki haalat batara -> Dukaan 'up' hai, bole toh khuli hai.

examples.hindi_explanation: Poochra 'Uth gaye kya?'. Short mein bas 'auf' bolte miya.

examples.english: I get up every morning at 7 o'clock.

examples.hindi_explanation: Verb separate ho gaya. Subah uthne ke liye yehi word use hota.

examples.english_explanation: Because we use 'müssen' (must), the verb 'aufstehen' stays together at the end.
examples.hindi_explanation: 'Müssen' (must) aa gaya na, toh doosra verb sentence ke aakhri mein full form mein jaata.

examples.english: I wait at least one hour.
examples.hindi_sentence: Main kam se kam ek ghanta wait kartau.
examples.english_explanation: Here, 'mindestens' modifies the time. 'Eine Stunde' is in the Accusative case because it answers 'how long?'.
examples.hindi_explanation: 'Mindestens' bolto minimum. Kitni der wait karre? Ek ghanta. Time bataare na, toh Accusative case lagana padta ustaad.

examples.hindi_sentence: Tum kam se kam 18 saal ke rehna.
examples.english_explanation: This is a simple statement of age. 'Mindestens' sets the lower limit.
examples.hindi_explanation: Age ki baat hori miya. 'Mindestens' bole toh 18 se kam nakko, usse zyada chalta.

examples.english: I need at least ten Euros.
examples.hindi_sentence: Mereku kam se kam dus Euro hona.
examples.english_explanation: The verb 'brauchen' (to need) takes the Accusative case. 'Mindestens' just tells us the amount.
examples.hindi_explanation: 'Brauchen' bolto zaroorat hona. Jo cheez ki zaroorat hai wo Accusative hoti. Kam se kam 10 Euro hona bole.

mnemonic: Das = Baby. Mittag (noon) + Essen (food).

examples.english_explanation: Here, 'Das Mittagessen' is the Subject, so it stays in the Nominative case.
examples.hindi_explanation: Khana Subject hai miya yahan, kuch action nai karra bas 'hai'. Toh 'Das' ich rehta.

examples.english_explanation: 'Wir' is the Subject doing the eating. 'Das Mittagessen' is the Object being eaten, so it is Accusative (but 'das' doesn't change).
examples.hindi_explanation: Hum khaare na, toh hum Subject. Khana khaaye jaara, toh wo Object (Accusative). Par 'Das' change nai hota miya, light lo.

examples.english_explanation: The preposition 'nach' (after) always triggers the Dative case. 'Das' changes to 'dem' in Dative.
examples.hindi_explanation: 'Nach' bole toh baad mein. Iske baad hamesha Dative lagana. 'Das' badal ke 'Dem' hojata. Yaad rakhlo ustaad.

mnemonic: Imagine meeting Mit (with) a friend.

examples.english_explanation: 'Mit' always requires the Dative case. 'Du' (you) changes to 'dir' in Dative.
examples.hindi_explanation: 'Mit' ke saath hamesha Dative aata. 'Du' (tum) badal ke 'Dir' ban jaata. Ratta maarlo isku.

examples.english_explanation: Bus is 'der Bus'. Because of 'mit', it becomes Dative, so 'der' changes to 'dem'.
examples.hindi_explanation: German mein 'se' nai bolte, 'ke saath' bolte gadi ke liye. 'Mit' hai toh 'Der Bus' ban gaya 'Dem Bus'. Dative rule hai miya.

examples.english_explanation: Pen is 'der Stift'. 'Mit' triggers Dative, changing 'der' to 'dem'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Pen ke 'saath' likhre na. Toh Dative lagao. 'Der' Stift ko 'Dem' Stift kardo.

mnemonic: Mit (with) + Bringen (bring).

details.conjugation_present: ich bringe mit, du bringst mit, er bringt mit

examples.english_explanation: This is a separable verb. 'Mit' goes to the end of the sentence.
examples.hindi_explanation: Ye tutne wala verb hai miya. 'Mit' ko utha ke sentence ke aakhri mein phek dena. 'Bring ... mit'.

examples.english: I am bringing my friend along.
examples.hindi_sentence: Main mere dost ko saath laarau.
examples.english_explanation: 'Freund' is the Direct Object (Accusative). 'Mein' becomes 'meinen'. 'Mit' goes to the end.
examples.hindi_explanation: Dost ko laare na, toh dost Accusative hai. 'Mein' ka 'Meinen' hogaya. Aur 'mit' last mein chipkana bhulna nakko.

examples.english_explanation: With a modal verb 'soll' (should), the main verb 'mitbringen' stays together and goes to the end.
examples.hindi_explanation: Jab 'Soll' (modal) aata na, toh verb tut'ta nahi. Pura 'mitbringen' end mein rehta. Saath mein hi rehte wo log.

mnemonic: Mit (with) + Kommen (come).

details.conjugation_present: ich komme mit, du kommst mit, er kommt mit

examples.english: Do you want to come along?
examples.english_explanation: Modal verb 'willst' implies we keep 'mitkommen' together at the end.
examples.hindi_explanation: 'Willst' aagaya na, toh 'mitkommen' jud ke rehta aur last mein aata. Tut'ta nai wo.

examples.english_explanation: Separable verb in present tense. 'Ich komme' ... 'mit' goes to the end.
examples.hindi_explanation: Present tense mein ye tut jaata ustaad. 'Komme' pehle, 'mit' aakhri mein. Beech mein 'gerne' daal diye.

examples.english: He is not coming along today.
examples.english_explanation: 'Er kommt' (he comes) ... 'mit' is at the very end. 'Nicht' negates the action.
examples.hindi_explanation: Wo nai aara. 'Kommt' idhar, 'mit' udhar last mein. Beech mein 'nahi' (nicht) ghusa diye.

mnemonic: Mit (with) + Machen (do) -> Do with others.

details.conjugation_present: ich mache mit, du machst mit, er macht mit

examples.hindi_sentence: Sab log hissa lere / saath mein karre.
examples.english_explanation: Separable verb. 'Machen' is conjugated for 'Alle', and 'mit' moves to the end.
examples.hindi_explanation: Ye bhi tutne wala verb hai. 'Machen' beech mein, 'mit' last mein. Sab milke karre kaam.

examples.hindi_sentence: Kya tum bhi karre saath mein?
examples.english_explanation: A question format. Conjugated verb 'Machst' comes first, prefix 'mit' is last.
examples.hindi_explanation: Sawaal puchre toh verb pehle aata. 'Machst' pehle, 'mit' aakhri mein. Simple hai miya.

examples.english_explanation: Modal verb 'müssen' holds the main verb 'mitmachen' together at the end.
examples.hindi_explanation: 'Müssen' (zaroori) hai na, toh verb ko todna nai. Pura 'mitmachen' last mein rakh dena.

mnemonic: Mit (with) + Nehmen (take).

details.conjugation_present: ich nehme mit, du nimmst mit, er nimmt mit

examples.english: I am taking the umbrella along.
examples.english_explanation: 'Schirm' (umbrella) is Masculine Accusative because it's being taken. 'Der' -> 'Den'. Verb is separated.
examples.hindi_explanation: Chaata lejaare na, toh wo object hai. Masculine 'Der' badal ke 'Den' hojata. Verb 'nehme...mit' tut gaya.

examples.english_explanation: 'Mich' is the Accusative form of 'Ich'. You are taking *me*.
examples.hindi_explanation: Mereku lejaare na, toh main object hun. Isliye 'Mich' bole. 'Nimmst' pehle, 'mit' last mein.

examples.english: We are taking the food to go.

examples.hindi_explanation: Khana lejaare (takeaway). Khana object hai, par 'Das' change nai hota. Tension nakko lo.

examples.hindi_explanation: Agar bada 'M' likhe toh subah, chota 'm' likhe toh kal. Yaad rakho ustaad.

mnemonic: Die = Woman. Imagine a Woman wearing a Mitts-e (Mütze) on her head.

examples.hindi_explanation: Main pehnau topi. Topi object hai. Feminine hai toh 'Eine' ich rehta change nai hota.

mnemonic: Imagine being Moody (müde) because you are tired.

examples.hindi_explanation: Thaka hua hun miya. Haalat kharaab hai.

examples.hindi_sentence: Kaam se main thak jaata hun.

examples.hindi_explanation: Muh kholo miya. 'Mund' object hai, 'Den' ban gaya. Verb 'aufmachen' hai.

examples.english_explanation: 'Im' = 'In dem'. Being INSIDE (static) uses Dative. 'Das' changes to 'dem'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Ab hum andar khade hai. Hilre nai (destination nai hai). Toh Dative aata. 'In dem' ko 'Im' bolte.

mnemonic: Die = Woman. Musik is Music.

examples.english_explanation: Direct object Accusative. 'Die Musik' stays 'die Musik'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Music sunrau. Music object hai. Feminine 'Die' change nai hota.

mnemonic: Imagine you Must (müssen) do it.

examples.english_explanation: Modal verb 'muss' conjugated. Main verb 'gehen' at the end.
examples.hindi_explanation: Jaana zaroori hai. 'Muss' pehle, 'gehen' aakhri mein.

examples.english_explanation: We have no choice but to wait.
examples.hindi_explanation: Wait karna padra. Koi option nai hai.

mnemonic: Die = Woman. Mutter is Mother.

mnemonic: Die = Woman. Imagine a female Neighbor (Nachbarin).

examples.english_explanation: Plural Accusative. Watching the news on TV.
examples.hindi_explanation: Plural hai ye. TV pe news dekhre.

mnemonic: Imagine the Next (nächste) one is near.

examples.hindi_explanation: Agla mahina. Masculine hai isliye 'Nächsten' bole.

mnemonic: Die = Woman. Nase is Nose.

mnemonic: Imagine Schl-echt (schlecht) is bad luck.

examples.english_explanation: Here, 'schlecht' is a predicative adjective appearing after the verb 'ist'. In this position, adjectives do not take any endings (declension), regardless of the noun's gender.
examples.hindi_explanation: Dekho ustaad, jab adjective 'ist' ke baad aata na, toh usku koi 'ending' nai lagti. Seedha 'schlecht' bol dene ka, chahe 'Das Wetter' ho ya kuch aur.

examples.hindi_sentence: Meri tabiyat kharaab lagri / Ulti jaisa hora.
examples.english_explanation: This is an impersonal construction. 'Mir' is the Dative form of 'Ich'. It literally translates to 'To me, it is bad'. We use this specific structure to express physical nausea.
examples.hindi_explanation: Ulti aari jaisa lagra toh 'Mir ist schlecht' bolna. 'Mir' (mere liye) Dative hai. Agar 'Ich bin schlecht' bole toh uska matlab 'Main bura insaan hun' hojata, sambhal ke!

examples.english_explanation: 'Schlecht' functions as an adverb here because it describes the verb 'spielt' (how he plays). In German, the adverb form is the same as the adjective form.
examples.hindi_explanation: Yahan 'schlecht' bata ra ke wo kaise khel ra. Ye adverb hai, lekin German mein adjective aur adverb dikhne mein same ich rehte.

mnemonic: Imagine Sluice (schließen) gate closing.

details.conjugation_present: ich schließe, du schließt, er schließt

examples.english_explanation: This is a formal Imperative (command). The verb 'schließen' comes first, followed by the polite subject 'Sie'. 'Die Tür' is the Accusative object receiving the action.
examples.hindi_explanation: Ye izzat wala order hai. 'Sie' lagaye isliye verb 'schließen' pura aaya. 'Die Tür' object hai, jisko band karre.

examples.english_explanation: Here, 'schließen' is used intransitively (the shop closes itself). 'Der Laden' is the Subject (Nominative). 'Um' is the preposition used for specific clock times.
examples.hindi_explanation: Dukaan (Subject) khud band hori. Time batane ke liye 'Um' lagate, jaise 'Um 8 Uhr'.

examples.english_explanation: This is an informal Imperative (Du-form) where the 'st' and 'du' are dropped from 'schließt du'. 'Deine Augen' is the Plural Accusative object.
examples.hindi_explanation: Ye dost ko bolre 'aankhein band kar'. 'Du' hata diye, bas 'Schließ' bole. 'Deine Augen' plural object hai.

mnemonic: Imagine a Slim (schlimm) chance is bad.

examples.english_explanation: 'Das' is the subject. 'Schlimm' acts as a predicate adjective, so no ending is needed. 'Nicht so' negates and modifies the intensity.
examples.hindi_explanation: Tension nakko lo. 'Das' subject hai, aur 'schlimm' last mein aaya toh change nai hota. Buri baat nai hai.

examples.english_explanation: 'Kopfschmerzen' is a Plural noun. Therefore, the adjective 'schlimm' takes the 'e' ending ('schlimme') to match the Plural Accusative case.
examples.hindi_explanation: Sar dard (Kopfschmerzen) plural maante German mein. Isliye 'schlimm' ke aage 'e' lagaya 'schlimme' banaya.

examples.english_explanation: Subject 'Die Lage' (Nominative). 'Schlimm' is the predicate adjective describing the state.
examples.hindi_explanation: Haalat (Die Lage) subject hai. 'Ist' ke baad adjective aaya toh same rehta, 'schlimm' ich.

mnemonic: Das = Baby. Imagine a Slot (Schloss) for a lock in a castle.

examples.english_explanation: 'Wir' is the Subject. 'Besuchen' is the verb. 'Das Schloss' is the Direct Object (Accusative). Since 'Schloss' is Neuter (das), the article 'das' remains unchanged in Accusative.
examples.hindi_explanation: Hum (subject) kila (object) dekhre. Neuter 'Das' object banne pe bhi 'Das' ich rehta. Change nai hota.

examples.english_explanation: Here 'Das Schloss' is the Subject (Nominative) of the sentence. 'Kaputt' is the adjective describing it.
examples.hindi_explanation: Yahan Taala subject hai, action nai karra bas kharaab hai. 'Das' nominative mein hai.

examples.english: The castle lies on the mountain.

examples.hindi_explanation: Kila pahad par hai, hil nai ra. Jab jagah fix ho, toh Dative lagate. 'An dem' milke 'Am' ban gaya.

examples.english_explanation: Here, 'selbstständig' is a predicate adjective used after the verb 'sein' (ist). In this position, adjectives do not take any endings.
examples.hindi_explanation: Jab adjective 'ist' ke baad aata na miya, toh usku koi ending nai lagti. Bas 'selbstständig' bolke chod dena.

examples.english_explanation: 'Sehr' acts as an adverb modifying the adjective 'selbstständig'. Again, no ending because it follows 'ist'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Bacchha bahut independent hai. Yahan bhi 'ist' ke baad hai isliye adjective change nai hota.

examples.english_explanation: Here it functions as an adverb describing *how* I work (modifying the verb 'arbeite'). Adverbs in German look exactly like the base form of the adjective.
examples.hindi_explanation: Main kaise kaam kartau? Khud se. Yahan ye adverb hai, par German mein adjective aur adverb same ich dikhte.

details.conjugation_present: ich ziehe um, du ziehst um, er zieht um

examples.english_explanation: This is a separable verb ('um' + 'ziehen'). In a simple sentence, the prefix 'um' moves to the very end.
examples.hindi_explanation: Ye tutne wala verb hai ustaad. 'Ziehen' beech mein aata, aur 'um' sentence ke aakhri mein phek dete.

examples.english: I have to change my clothes.
examples.english_explanation: When changing clothes, it's reflexive: 'sich umziehen'. 'Mich' is the Accusative reflexive pronoun for 'Ich'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Jab kapde badalte na, toh 'mich' (khud ko) lagana padta. German style hai ye.

examples.english_explanation: In the Perfect tense (past), we use the helper verb 'sein' (ist) because moving involves a change of location.
examples.hindi_explanation: Wo shift hogaya. Jab jagah badalte na, toh past tense mein 'sein' (ist) use karte, 'haben' nahi.

mnemonic: Us -> Unser.

examples.english_explanation: 'Haus' is a Neuter noun (das Haus). For Neuter Nominative, the possessive 'unser' takes no ending.
examples.hindi_explanation: Ghar (Haus) neuter hai. Isliye 'Unser' ke aage kuch nai lagta. Bas 'Unser Haus'.

examples.english_explanation: 'Kinder' is Plural. Possessive pronouns take an '-e' ending for plurals in the Nominative case -> 'Unsere'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Bacchhe (Kinder) plural hain. Plural mein 'e' lagana padta end mein: 'Unsere'.

examples.hindi_sentence: Hum apne kutte se pyaar karte.
examples.english_explanation: 'Hund' is a Masculine noun and is the Direct Object (Accusative). Masculine Accusative endings are '-en', so 'unser' becomes 'unseren'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Kutta (Hund) masculine hai aur object hai yahan. Isliye 'unser' ke aage 'en' lagake 'unseren' banaye.

mnemonic: Wise people Know (wissen) things.

details.conjugation_present: ich weiß, du weißt, er weiß

examples.english_explanation: 'Wissen' is used for knowing facts. It has an irregular conjugation: 'ich weiß' (not 'ich wisse').
examples.hindi_explanation: Jab koi fact ya baat pata ho toh 'wissen' use karte. 'Ich weiß' bolte, 'Ich wisse' nai.

examples.english: Do you know where he is?
examples.english_explanation: Main clause 'Weißt du' is a question (Verb first). The second part is a subordinate clause starting with 'wo', so the verb 'ist' goes to the very end.
examples.hindi_explanation: Sawaal puchre 'Weißt du?'. Jab 'wo' (kahan) beech mein aata, toh uska verb 'ist' sentence ke dum pe (last mein) chala jaata.

examples.english_explanation: The question word 'Wer' (who) is treated as a 3rd person singular subject (like 'er'), so the verb is 'weiß'.
examples.hindi_explanation: 'Wer' (kaun) ko hamesha singular samajhte, jaise 'wo'. Isliye 'weiß' lagaye.

mnemonic: Wo (where) + Her (here) -> Where from?

examples.english_explanation: Standard question structure: Question word (Woher) + Verb (kommst) + Subject (du).
examples.hindi_explanation: Tum kahan se aare? 'Woher' pehle, phir verb 'kommst', phir 'du'.

examples.english: Where did you get that from?
examples.english_explanation: Asking about the source of an object. 'Das' is the Accusative object.
examples.hindi_explanation: Ye kahan se uthaye? 'Woher' source puchne ke liye hai.

examples.english: How do you know that? (Where from...)
examples.english_explanation: Asking about the source of information. Literally: 'Where-from know you that?'
examples.hindi_explanation: Tumku ye baat kahan se maloom hui?

mnemonic: Wo (where) + Hin (there) -> Where to?

examples.english_explanation: 'Wohin' asks for a destination or direction of movement.

examples.english_explanation: Asking for a destination to place an object. 'Legen' implies movement to a place.

mnemonic: Wohnen sounds like Won (one) place to live.

details.conjugation_present: ich wohne, du wohnst, er wohnt

examples.english_explanation: 'In' is used for cities. Since living is static (not movement), it is technically Dative, but cities usually don't have articles.

examples.english_explanation: 'Wo' is the question word for static location.
'Bei' is used when living with people. 'Bei' always takes Dative, so 'seine Eltern' (Plural) becomes 'seinen Eltern'.
examples.hindi_explanation: Kisi ke ghar pe rehne ko 'Bei' bolte. 'Bei' ke baad Dative lagta, isliye 'seinen Eltern' bola.

mnemonic: Will / Wollen.

details.conjugation_present: ich will, du willst, er will

examples.english_explanation: 'Wollen' (conjugated 'will') is a modal verb. It pushes the main verb 'schlafen' to the end of the sentence.
examples.hindi_explanation: Dil se chahna. 'Will' second position pe, aur 'sona' (schlafen) aakhri mein.

examples.english_explanation: Here 'wollen' expresses a plan. It creates a bracket with 'essen gehen' at the end.
examples.hindi_explanation: Humara plan hai khane jaane ka.

mnemonic: Wonder-bar -> Wonderful.

examples.hindi_explanation: Khana zabardast hai. 'Ist' ke baad ending nai lagti.

examples.english_explanation: The particle 'ja' adds emphasis or surprise.

mnemonic: To -> Zu.
